citation.article-title: Turicella otitidis gen. nov., sp. nov., a coryneform bacterium isolated from patients with otitis media.

p.s: Turicella (Tu.ri.cel'la. Turicum, proper name Turicum; L. dim. suff. -ella; N. L. fem. n. Turicella, pertaining to Turicum, the Latin name of Zürich, Switzerland, where the first isolates were collected)

Cells are gram-positive, nonmotile, non-spore-forming diphtheroids that occur as single cells or are arranged in V-shaped forms or palisades, Colonies are circular, convex, and creamy in color and range from 1.0 to 2.0 mm in diameter after 48 h of incubation at 37°C on sheep blood agar.
The cell wall contains meso-diaminopimelic acid, arabinose, and galactose.
The principal menaquinones are MK-(10) and MK-(11).
The straight-chain saturated fatty acids are mainly palmitic and stearic acids.
Oleic acid is the predominant unsaturated fatty acid.
The G+C content of the DNA is 65 to 72 mol%.
The type species is Turicella otitidis.
